Jennifer, thanks for coming on.
Oh, great to be here.
Let's start with this.
Your book talks about three identifying elements of sexuality.
Explain what you meant.
Well, I tried to break sexuality down to its components as I see it.
It's not simply who you're dating.
It's how you see yourself.
It's who you have sex with.
And it's also who you kind of set up your home with.
And so it's these kind, sometimes, competing elements of identity that create sexuality.
And I think it's often erroneously boiled down to just who you have sex with.
You also talk about sex not being the main element of bisexuality.
Now, I'm reading from the book here, where you say, and I'm quoting.
If I'm dating a man, I'm straight.
If I'm dating a woman, I'm a lesbian.
But sexuality is not who you sleep with, it's who you are.
It doesn't change according to who is standing next to you."" So here's my question: How do you determine bisexuality?
Is it a state of mind?
It is a state of mind, and I think it's just such a core element of my identity that I've probably had maybe my entire life.

I'm not saying that I always knew I was bisexual, but the frustration once - I kind of grew up having boyfriends, once I began having girlfriends, the first woman that came into my life, I was sort of shocked by how suddenly I was a lesbian.
And everybody saw me differently, and I was seen as being part of a totally different community.
And my relationship was different and I was alien in some ways.
And I'm from Fargo, North Dakota, and I yearn to be connected to all elements of my life, including my past.
And I kind of slowly came to realize that this was a very common sort of social justice, civil rights story, which is that people who are marginalized don't have the opportunity to self-define.
And at a certain point they realize, no, wait, it is my right to explain who I am.
I'm actually expert on who I am, not the outside world.
And since I did that, I became more comfortable with this term, bisexuality, although I don't want to impose it on anyone who, you know, doesn't like that word to describe themselves.
And I think that I've come to the conclusion that all of my relationships were valid.
None of them were just a phase or some weird thing I was doing just because society told me to do it or because I was in college suddenly so I dated a girl, you know.
It was actually coming from me, not from the outside world.

What distinguishes one gender's bisexuality from the others?
Well, I really did focus on women and bisexuality, and part of that is because I'm a feminist writer.
And even though men are a huge part of feminism, I've always tended to kind of write from a personal place and then extrapolate from there, and so I tend to write more about women.
